definition: lackey/errand boy/lit. runner before a carriage
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]
front/forward/ahead/first/top (followed by a number)/future/ago/before/BC (e.g. 前293年)/former/formerly
soldier/servant/to finish/to die/finally/at last/pawn in Chinese chess
variant of 卒[zu2]
variant of 猝[cu4]

sentences.english: The other two federal forts, however, became pawns in a game of war or peace.
sentences.chinese: 而其它两座要塞则成为战争或和平游戏当中的马前卒。

sentences.english: So he put aside his dignity, they are willing to Wu to become a pawn.
sentences.chinese: 于是他放下尊严，甘愿到吴国去当马前卒。

sentences.english: Father made a general, his son or a pawn.
sentences.chinese: 父亲做了将军，儿子还是马前卒。

sentences.english: Father has already acted as General , the son has been only a pawn.
sentences.chinese: 父亲已做了将军，儿子还只是马前卒。

sentences.english: The father is always a captain, while his son is still a soldier.
sentences.chinese: 父亲已做了将军，儿子还只是马前卒。

sentences.english: His father has done a general, his son was just a pawn.
sentences.chinese: 父亲已做了将军，儿子还只是马前卒。

sentences.english: The prime minister was a mere tool in the hands of the country's president.
sentences.chinese: 那个总理只不过是该国总统的马前卒。

definition: hunting dog/hound/(fig.) running dog/lackey
to act as accomplice to the tiger/to help a villain do evil (idiom)
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
daring vanguard/pioneer/leading figure
to stand out (among a group)/distinguished
(old) itinerant political adviser/(fig.) lobbyist/go-between/mouthpiece/also pr. [shuo1 ke4]
hawks and hounds/(fig.) running dogs/hired thugs
dog's leg/fig. one who follows a villain/henchman/hired thug
sb who goes whichever way the wind blows/sb with no mind of their own/easily swayed person/opportunist
scapegoat
to charge and break through enemy lines
scapegoat/fall guy
cannon fodder
to use (sb) as a tool
ambition of wild wolves (idiom); rapacious designs
sit on the mountain and watch the tigers fight/watch in safety whilst others fight then reap the rewards when both sides are exhausted (idiom)
